values: In light of the chapter not being ready yet, we're posting an email sent to Mandi's Baby Whitty account. It will come into play later on in the story. Possibly. So, like, the other day I was doing some stuff, and I realized that I would rather be doing some other stuff, so instead of doing the thing that I was doing, I did something else, though still not what I was trying to think about when the makeshift burrito corridor barred the basket-weaving meatloaf maker XP 3000, but then I was like, "Whoa, there's a cordoned off monkey in my pasta sandwich," and I was like, "No way a monkey's staying in there!" so I wrapped up a skillet of tinfoil and rammed it into the transistor radio, which worked just fine for redialing the radio station, but didn't do much in the way of rewiring the microwave, so I decided to rethink my strategy and redouble my bubble, but then it became obvious that the shell of the camera wasn't going to work if I didn't first fire a photon torpedo, but where was I going to get a torpedo at this time of night? Instead I chose to relinquish command to Captain Mazymuffin, who was just out of the academy. While he barreled down the hatchway, I distorted a few key masts from the aft quadrent of the forward bulkhead, but this didn't help much, so I retired for the evening to a Barry White CD for dinner. It went down smoothly. And that's why I believe in saving the forrest fires today.

In honor of school starting and the authors' schedules being completely fucked up, leaving them both morbidly depressed, Pointless Angst will take a one-week hiatus.

Sorry.

As I watched the reflection of the car on the water come closer and closer, I thought back to Nam...

We were in the foxhole we'd dug only moments before. Muddy, bloody, and all-around disorientated, I listened while Sarge gave us a pep-talk. "Now, none of you worry, we'll get out of here fine, every one of us. You just gotta get out there and blow the piss outta the gooks."

"Thanks, Sarge. That'll be bloody helpful when they're blowing the bajesus out of us. And for what? I mean honestly, WHAT THE HELL IS THIS WAR FOR?" I shouted, not realizing I had even opened my mouth.

"For peace, you un-American bastard! HOW CAN WE HAVE PEACE WITHOUT MERCILESS BLOODSHED? ANSWER ME THAT!!"

I glared at Sarge for a moment, then turned away. Sarge moved on.

"For beer," whispered a tall man sitting next to me. He winked and handed me a bottle. I grinned and took a swig. Good shit.

"What brings you to the Charlies?" I asked, trying to look like I drank all the time. Truth be told, this was my first real drink, but I wanted to impress him.

"Ran outta cash. You know how it goes. Nowhere else to go..." He shrugged. "Actually, I'm interested in these little babies," he said, handing me what looked like a beanie baby dog made out of tinfoil. I raised my eyebrows and looked at the dog. In my mind, I wanted to ask him what the fuck this little thing was, but I merely nodded as if I dealt with crazy people every day.

"It will not poo in people's yards," he explained.

"Of course not. Would you like to take a nap?" I said very slowly.

"No... I'm not sure I introduced myself. My name is--" but as he said his name the damn Gooks opened fire. All I made out was "Claude." Eventually I would learn he was a scientist of sorts. He became known as "Mad Scientist Claude."

Then again, he might have said "Maude," or perhaps even "Larry." The alcohol went straight to my head. As I blew the brains out of some dude I couldn't even see, brightly colored circus animals danced in the ranks of our enemy. 

"Holy shit!" I yelled. I mean, they had all these animals on their side. And they were all.... RADIOACTIVE looking....

I looked at the rifle. Man, that would make a comfy pillow, I thought. I could try it out... I wouldn't really fall asleep or anything... the next thing I knew, I was laying on a stretcher next to an arm that looked a bit like Mad Scientist Claude's. I poked it experimentally, still a little drunk and hungover.

"Would you mind not poking my limbs?" Asked Mad Scientist Claude. I looked at him. Then I looked at his arm. His arm was four feet away from him.

"Wow... you really AREN'T an idiot... you're a magician!" I said, passing out.

I woke up in a hospital, bandaged, confused, and dreadfully hungover.

I thought about Little Bobby as I lit the cigarette. Little Bobby hated the harsh scents that accompanied my vast array of smokable cancer sticks, and pinched them out between his two nerveless, unfeeling fingers whenever he could.

That damned dirty kid. Fucking punk. Where was he now, huh? Couldn't even handle a bullet between the eyes.

If only my identical twin hadn't murdered that poor lady's mother... Her gallbladder exploded when she did it. I had to kill Little Bobby and take his so my twin would live.

A tear rolled down my face as I took a puff of the cigarette. Damn kid, didn't know what was coming until I pointed my nine between his eyes.

Made a terrible mess all over the carpet. But that's beside the point.

"What are you thinking about?" asked Larissa.

"Little Bobby." Larissa nodded. An self-proclaimed assassin-slash-model by trade, she was as dumb as Barbie on speed, but she had the uncanny ability to predict the future.

"It was in the stars," she murmured, trying to comfort me. She held out the phone. "A call for you."

"I don't want any fucking call," I said, taking the phone. It rang shortly. "Speak."

"Christy, dah-ling." I froze.

"Mandi."

"So glad you remember the name. Do you remember Little Bobby, too? Or have you forgotten him, and the stain I found on my carpet that night?"

"I told you. Larissa needed the gallbladder."

"But I needed Bobby's memories! You know I can't remember anything that happened to me during the last four years... but he did. And now I'll never know!" She wailed loudly in my ear.

"So you won't know who  killed your mom's hairdresser's son's dermatologist. Worse things have happened." But in my mind, I knew. It had been Little Bobby who had killed him. Mom's hairdresser's son's dermatologist.

"Look, let's go out. I'll buy us some Mr. Pibbs. We'll have a good time, forget this ever happened." I tried to cover her screeches.

A silence.

"Mr. Pibb?" She asked. Then she knew. I knew she knew. She knew I knew she knew. I knew she knew I knew she knew.

"You haven't suggested we go out for Mr. Pibbs since the last time you were..." 

I groaned inwardly. 

"Pregnant," she whispered.

I rested my head in my hands. 

"Who's the father?" she asked quietly.

"I don't..." I tried to squelch the sob rising in my throat. My mind wandered back to a time I'd almost forgotten. A better time...

It had been last Tuesday... My neighbor's second cousin's best friend's grandma's sheltie had been attacked by an evil robot dog bent on world domination, created by my former boyfriend who I stole from Mandi, Mad Scientist Claude. I didn't even like him that much, I was just still mad at Mandi for wearing the same prom dress as me way back in high school.

All the other girls laughed. Little Bobby's girlfriend died that night... she jumped off the bridge at Two Oaks after I told her her butt looked huge in her dress. Her last words still haunt me...

"NOT AS BIG AS YOURS, YOU WHORE!" I choked back a sob as my thoughts returned to the present. My butt had looked great, and she'd known it... but I never got to tell her...

I had been using the muscle toning pills that had disappeared from her backpack just two days ago. She hadn't the faintest idea where they'd gone. I never told her, and now the guilt was eating me alive.

"Christy?" Mandi sounded worried. "Still there?"

"Yep," I whispered, wiping a tear from my cheek.

"Who's the father?" 

"I... I don't know." It was one of the three, I knew--either Mad Scientist Claude, or the dermatologist that Little Bobby had killed, or...

Oh God...

It might have been Little Bobby.

Suddenly the memories came rushing at me... Mandi laughing, pointing the gun, pointing the gun at the poodle, Mandi laughing, laughing as the small furry dog looked up at her with eyes, eyes that screamed, screamed and pleaded... "Not like this, not like this."

"Why the fuck should I tell you?" I screamed, slamming the phone down. I remembered it was a cell phone, and so I angrily pushed the "bye-bye" button.

The screen was cracked. I could see my own horrified reflection staring back at me as I screamed.

I fell to the ground, trying not to let the panic show on my face. Truth be told, it could be any of them. I honestly didn't know who--the aliens had been nice, but I could not understand their strange language... I could still see them, in my nightmares.
